rComments: His tests are super hard. Class is super dry. No homework or extra credit are given. Grading is solely based on midterms and finals.

I really like Professor Gorry. His tests can be pretty difficult, but overall I think he's a really good teacher. He definitely knows his stuff, is super nice and very approachable. I went to his office hours a lot during the quarter, and he was always very helpful. Go to class, get a copy of the textbook (and actually read it)  and you'll do fine.

Professor Gorry isn't as bad as some people are saying.  His class is dull/boring, but it is not hard by any means.  Just reading the chapter one, or doing his study guide guarantees a high grade.  He also curved our first exam so that a 35/100 was a C- for those who failed. What a nice guy :)

Gorry is a nice guy. Lectures are pretty straightforward, however, he leaves it up to you to make it interesting for yourself. Otherwise, make sure you pay attention when he derives equations on the board. That is the key to this class. Go to MSI sections--absolutely incredibly helpful. You have to put in time to do well in this class.

Don't even bother going to lecture, he basically reads off the power points. Tests were pretty difficult, he did not give any study guides/questions to study off of. Take intermediate macro with some other professor if you can!

Don't bother showing up for this class. Gorry spends the entire class rambling about a particular graph he found interesting. Then he spends about 5 minutes on the formulas that you actually need to know for the exams. I could read a chapter in the book faster than he could lecture on it. Read the book for an A.

I usually go to all my classes, but after the first week and a half, I was literally unable to sit through an entire class. I made better use of my that hour and a half studying the material somewhere else, listening to his lecture just makes things more confusing. Grading is somewhat easy if you take time to study the material by yourself, a lot.
